Language codes

<http://glottolog.org/resource/languoid/id/stan1293>|^[3]
<#cite_note-Glottolog-3>
Linguasphere <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguasphere_Observatory>

Anglospeak.svg <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Anglospeak.svg>
  Countries of the world where English is a majority native language
  Countries where English is official but not a majority native language
*This article contains IPA
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet> phonetic
symbols.* Without proper rendering support
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet#Typefaces>,
you may see question marks, boxes, or other symbols
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replacement_character> instead of Unicode
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unicode> characters. For an introductory
guide on IPA symbols, see Help:IPA
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA>.

*English* is a West Germanic language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Germanic_language> that was first
spoken in early medieval England
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_England> and is now a global
/lingua franca <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lingua_franca>/.^[4]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a6-4> ^[5]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWardhaugh201055-5> Named after the Angles
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angles>, one of the Germanic tribes
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germanic_tribes> that migrated to England
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England>, it ultimately derives its name
from the Anglia (Angeln) <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angeln>
peninsula in the Baltic Sea <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltic_Sea>.
It is closely related to the Frisian languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frisian_languages>, but its vocabulary
has been significantly influenced by other Germanic languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germanic_languages>, particularly Norse
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Norse> (a North Germanic language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Germanic_languages>), as well as by
Latin <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_language> and Romance
languages <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romance_languages>, especially
French <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language>.^[6]
<#cite_note-Wolff-6>

English has developed over the course of more than 1,400 years. The
earliest forms of English, a set of Anglo-Frisian dialects
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Frisian_languages> brought to Great
Britain <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Britain> by Anglo-Saxon
settlers <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Saxons> in the 5th
century, are called Old English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_English>. Middle English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_English> began in the late 11th
century with the Norman conquest of England
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England> and was a
period in which the language was influenced by French.^[7]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b30-7> Early Modern English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_Modern_English> began in the late
15th century with the introduction of the printing press
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Printing_press> to London, the printing
of the King James Bible <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Bible>
and the start of the Great Vowel Shift
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Vowel_Shift>.^[8] <#cite_note-8>

Through the worldwide influence of the British Empire
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Empire>, modern English spread
around the world from the 17th to mid-20th centuries. Through all types
of printed and electronic media, and spurred by the emergence of the
United States as a global superpower
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superpower>, English has become the
leading language <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_language> of
international discourse and the /lingua franca/
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_as_a_lingua_franca> in many
regions and professional contexts such as science, navigation and
law.^[9] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Routes_of_English-9>

English is the third most spoken native language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_languages_by_number_of_native_speakers>
in the world, after Standard Chinese
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Chinese> and Spanish
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language>.^[10]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEthnologue2010-10> It is the most widely learned
second language <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_language> and is
either the official language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Official_language> or one of the official
languages in almost 60 sovereign states
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_territorial_entities_where_English_is_an_official_language>.
There are more people who have learned it as a second language than
there are native speakers. English is the most commonly spoken language
in the United Kingdom <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom>,
the United States <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States>, Canada
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canada>, Australia
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia>, Ireland
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ireland> and New Zealand
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand>, and it is widely spoken in
some areas of the Caribbean <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caribbean>,
Africa and South Asia <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Asia>.^[11]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b108–109-11> It is a co-official language
of the United Nations
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Official_languages_of_the_United_Nations>, the
European Union
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Languages_of_the_European_Union> and many
other world and regional international organisations. It is the most
widely spoken Germanic language, accounting for at least 70% of speakers
of this Indo-European branch. English has a vast vocabulary
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vocabulary>, though counting how many
words any language has is impossible.^[12]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHowManyWords2015-12> ^[13]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlgeo1999-13>

Modern English grammar <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_grammar>
is the result of a gradual change from a typical Indo-European dependent
marking pattern with a rich inflectional
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflection> morphology
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphology_(linguistics)> and relatively
free word order <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word_order> to a mostly
analytic <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytic_language> pattern with
little inflection <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflection>, a fairly
fixed SVO word order <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SVO_word_order> and
a complex syntax <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax>.^[14]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994539-14> Modern English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_English> relies more on auxiliary
verbs <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Auxiliary_verb> and word order
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word_order> for the expression of complex
tenses <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatical_tense>, aspect
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatical_aspect> and mood
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatical_mood>, as well as passive
constructions <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Passive_voice>,
interrogatives <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interrogative> and some
negation <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negation>. Despite noticeable
variation among the accents
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_accents> and dialects of English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_dialects> used in different
countries and regions – in terms of phonetics
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonetics> and phonology
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonology>, and sometimes also vocabulary
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vocabulary>, grammar
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammar> and spelling
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_spelling_differences> –
English-speakers from around the world are able to communicate with one
another with relative ease
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility>.

    Classification

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Europe_germanic-languages_2.PNG>
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Europe_germanic-languages_2.PNG>
*Anglic languages <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglic_languages>*
  English
  Scots <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scots_language>
*Anglo-Frisian languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Frisian_languages>*
Anglic and
  Frisian <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frisian_languages>
*North Sea Germanic languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Sea_Germanic_languages>*
Anglo-Frisian and
  Low German/Low Saxon <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low_German>
*West Germanic languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Germanic_languages>*
North Sea Germanic and
  Dutch <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_language>
  German <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language>
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Westgermanic_English_tree.svg>
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Westgermanic_English_tree.svg>
Phylogenetic tree <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree>
showing the historical relations between the languages of the West
Germanic branch of the Germanic languages

English is an Indo-European language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indo-European_language> and belongs to
the West Germanic
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Germanic_languages> group of the
Germanic languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germanic_languages>.^[15]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBammesberger199229–30-15> Old English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_English> originated
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_settlement_of_Britain> from a
Germanic tribal and linguistic continuum
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialect_continuum> along the coast of the
North Sea <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Sea>, whose languages are
now known as the Anglo-Frisian
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Frisian_languages> subgroup within
West Germanic. As such, the modern Frisian languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frisian_languages> are the closest living
relatives of Modern English. Low German/Low Saxon
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low_German> is also closely related, and
sometimes English, the Frisian languages, and Low German are grouped
together as the Ingvaeonic (North Sea Germanic) languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ingvaeonic_languages>, though this
grouping remains debated.^[16]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBammesberger199230-16> Old English evolved into
Middle English <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_English>, which in
turn evolved into Modern English.^[17]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTERobinson1992-17> Particular dialects of Old and
Middle English also developed into a number of other Anglic languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglic_languages>, including Scots
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scots_language>^[18]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine198256–65-18> and the extinct Fingallian
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fingallian> and Forth and Bargy (Yola)
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forth_and_Bargy_dialect> dialects of
Ireland.^[19] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBarry198286–87-19>

Like Icelandic <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Icelandic_language> and
Faroese <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faroese_language>, the
development of English on the British Isles
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Isles> isolated it from the
continental Germanic languages and influences, and has since undergone
substantial evolution. English is thus not mutually intelligible
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutual_intelligibility> with any
continental Germanic language, differing in vocabulary
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexis_(linguistics)>, syntax
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax>, and phonology
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonology>, although some, such as Dutch
or Frisian, do show strong affinities with English, especially with its
earlier stages.^[20] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarbert2007-20>

Unlike Icelandic or Faroese, the long history of invasions of the
British Isles by other peoples and languages, particularly Old Norse
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Norse> and Norman French
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_language>, left a profound mark of
their own on the language, such that English shares substantial
vocabulary and grammar similarities with many languages outside its
linguistic clades <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clades>, while also
being unintelligible with any of those languages. Some scholars have
even argued that English can be considered a mixed language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixed_language> or a creole
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creole_language> – a theory called the
Middle English creole hypothesis
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_English_creole_hypothesis>.
Although the high degree of influence from these languages on the
vocabulary and grammar of Modern English is widely acknowledged, most
specialists in language contact do not consider English to be a true
mixed language.^[21] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomasonKaufman1988264–265-21>
^[22] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWatts2011Chapter_4-22>

English is classified as a Germanic language because it shares
innovations <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_change> with other
Germanic languages such as Dutch
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutch_language>, German
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language>, and Swedish
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swedish_language>.^[23]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDurrell2006-23> These shared innovations show that
the languages have descended from a single common ancestor called
Proto-Germanic <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proto-Germanic>. Some
shared features of Germanic languages include the use of modal verbs
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_verb>, the division of verbs into
strong <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germanic_strong_verb> and weak
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germanic_weak_verb> classes, and the
sound changes affecting Proto-Indo-European
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proto-Indo-European_language> consonants,
known as Grimm's <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grimm%27s_law> and
Verner's laws <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Verner%27s_law>. English is
classified as an Anglo-Frisian language because Frisian and English
share other features, such as the palatalisation
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palatalization_(sound_change)> of
consonants that were velar consonants in Proto-Germanic (see
Phonological history of Old English § Palatalization
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_history_of_Old_English#Palatalization>).^[24]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönigvan_der_Auwera1994-24>

  * English /s*i*ng/, /s*a*ng/, /s*u*ng/; Dutch /z*i*ngen/, /z*o*ng/,
    /gez*o*ngen/; German /s*i*ngen/, /s*a*ng/, /ges*u*ngen/ (strong verb)
  * English /laugh/, /laugh*ed*/; Dutch and German /lachen/, /lach*te*/
    (weak verb)
  * English /foot/, Dutch /voet/, German /Fuß/, Norwegian and Swedish
    /fot/ (initial /f/ derived from Proto-Indo-European *p through
    Grimm's law)

    (Compare Latin /pes/, stem <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Word_stem>
    /ped-/; Modern Greek πόδι /pódi/; Russian
    <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_language> под /pod/; Sanskrit
    <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sanskrit> पद् /pád/)

  * English /cheese/, Frisian /tsiis/ (/ch/ and /ts/ from
    palatalisation); German /Käse/ and Dutch /kaas/ (/k/ without
    palatalisation)


    History

Main article: History of English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_English>


      Proto-Germanic to Old English

Main article: Old English <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_English>
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Beowulf_Cotton_MS_Vitellius_A_XV_f._132r.jpg>

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Beowulf_Cotton_MS_Vitellius_A_XV_f._132r.jpg>
The opening to the Old English epic poem /Beowulf
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beowulf>/, handwritten
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manuscript> in half-uncial script
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Half-uncial>:
/Hƿæt ƿē Gārde/na ingēar dagum þēod cyninga / þrym ge frunon.../
"Listen! We of the Spear-Danes from days of yore have heard of the glory
of the folk-kings..."

The earliest form of English is called Old English or Anglo-Saxon (c.
550–1066 CE). Old English developed from a set of North Sea Germanic
dialects <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ingvaeonic_languages> originally
spoken along the coasts of Frisia
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frisia>, Lower Saxony
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lower_Saxony>, Jutland
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jutland>, and Southern Sweden
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sweden> by Germanic tribes known as the
Angles <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angles>, Saxons
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saxons>, and Jutes
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jutes>. In the fifth century, the
Anglo-Saxons settled Britain
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_settlement_of_Britain> as the
Roman economy and administration collapsed
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End_of_Roman_rule_in_Britain>. By the
seventh century, the Germanic language of the Anglo-Saxons became
dominant in Britain
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celtic_language-death_in_England>,
replacing the languages of Roman Britain
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Britain> (43–409 CE): Common
Brittonic <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Brittonic>, a Celtic
language <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celtic_languages>, and Latin
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin>, brought to Britain by the Roman
occupation
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caesar%27s_invasions_of_Britain>.^[25]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollingwoodMyres1936-25> ^[26]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddolLeithSwann_et_al.2007-26> ^[27]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBlenchSpriggs1999-27> /England/ and /English/
(originally /Ænglaland/ and /Ænglisc/) are named after the Angles.^[28]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBosworthToller1921-28>

Old English was divided into four dialects: the Anglian dialects,
Mercian <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercian_dialect> and Northumbrian
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northumbrian_dialect>, and the Saxon
dialects, Kentish
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kentish_dialect_(Old_English)> and West
Saxon <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Saxon_dialect>.^[29]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbell19594-29> Through the educational reforms of
King Alfred <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alfred_the_Great> in the
ninth century and the influence of the kingdom of Wessex
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wessex>, the West Saxon dialect became
the standard written variety
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_language>.^[30]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEToon1992Chapter:_Old_English_Dialects-30> The epic
poem <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epic_poetry> /Beowulf
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beowulf>/ is written in West Saxon, and
the earliest English poem, /Cædmon's Hymn
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%C3%A6dmon%27s_Hymn>/, is written in
Northumbrian.^[31] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDonoghue2008-31> Modern English
developed mainly from Mercian, but the Scots language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scots_language> developed from
Northumbrian. A few short inscriptions from the early period of Old
English were written using a runic script
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_runes>.^[32]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGneuss201323-32> By the sixth century, a Latin
alphabet <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_English_Latin_alphabet> was
adopted, written with half-uncial
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Half-uncial> letterforms
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Letterform>. It included the runic
letters /wynn <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wynn>/ ⟨/ƿ/⟩ and /thorn
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thorn_(letter)>/ ⟨/þ/⟩, and the modified
Latin letters /eth <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eth>/ ⟨/ð/⟩, and /ash
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%86>/ ⟨/æ/⟩.^[32]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGneuss201323-32> ^[33]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDenisonHogg200630–31-33>

Old English is very different from Modern English and difficult for
21st-century English speakers to understand. Its grammar was similar to
that of modern German <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/German_language>,
and its closest relative is Old Frisian
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Frisian>. Nouns, adjectives,
pronouns, and verbs <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_English_grammar>
had many more inflectional endings and forms
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflectional_morphology>, and word order
was much freer <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pragmatic_word_order> than
in Modern English. Modern English has case forms
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatical_case> in pronouns (/he/,
/him/, /his/) and a few verb endings (/I have/, /he has/), but Old
English had case endings in nouns as well, and verbs had more person
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatical_person> and number
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammatical_number> endings.^[34]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHogg1992Chapter_3._Phonology_and_Morphology-34>
^[35] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith2009-35> ^[36]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTETraskTrask2010-36>

The translation of Matthew 8:20 from 1000 CE shows examples of case
endings (nominative <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominative_case>
plural, accusative <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accusative_case>
plural, genitive <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genitive_case> singular)
and a verb ending (present <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Present_tense>
plural):

    /Foxas habbað holu and heofonan fuglas nest/
    Fox-as habb-að hol-u and heofon-an fugl-as nest-∅
    fox-NOM.PL have-PRS.PL hole-ACC.PL and heaven-GEN.SG bird-NOM.PL
    nest-ACC.PL
    "Foxes have holes and the birds of heaven nests"^[37]
    <#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass200646–47-37> 


      Middle English

Main article: Middle English <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_English>
/Englischmen þeyz hy hadde fram þe bygynnyng þre manner speche,
Souþeron, Northeron, and Myddel speche in þe myddel of þe lond, …
Noþeles by comyxstion and mellyng, furst wiþ Danes, and afterward wiþ
Normans, in menye þe contray longage ys asperyed, and som vseþ strange
wlaffyng, chyteryng, harryng, and garryng grisbytting/.

Although, from the beginning, Englishmen had three manners of speaking,
southern, northern and midlands speech in the middle of the country, …
Nevertheless, through intermingling and mixing, first with Danes and
then with Normans, amongst many the country language has arisen, and
some use strange stammering, chattering, snarling, and grating gnashing.
“
”

John of Trevisa <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_of_Trevisa>, ca.
1385^[38] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHogg2006360–361-38>

In the period from the 8th to the 12th century, Old English gradually
transformed through language contact
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_contact> into Middle English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Middle_English>. Middle English is often
arbitrarily defined as beginning with the conquest of England
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England> by William
the Conqueror <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_the_Conqueror> in
1066, but it developed further in the period from 1200–1450.

First, the waves of Norse colonisation of northern parts of the British
Isles in the 8th and 9th centuries put Old English into intense contact
with Old Norse <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Norse>, a North
Germanic <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Germanic> language. Norse
influence was strongest in the Northeastern varieties of Old English
spoken in the Danelaw <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Danelaw> area
around York, which was the centre of Norse colonisation; today these
features are still particularly present in Scots
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scots_language> and Northern English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_England_English>. However the
centre of norsified English seems to have been in the Midlands
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Midlands> around Lindsey
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kingdom_of_Lindsey>, and after 920 CE
when Lindsey was reincorporated into the Anglo-Saxon polity, Norse
features spread from there into English varieties that had not been in
intense contact with Norse speakers. Some elements of Norse influence
that persist in all English varieties today are the pronouns beginning
with /th-/ (/they, them, their/) which replaced the Anglo-Saxon pronouns
with /h-/ (/hie, him, hera/).^[39]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThomasonKaufman1988284–290-39>

With the Norman conquest of England
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England> in 1066, the
now norsified Old English language was subject to contact with the Old
Norman <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Norman> language, a Romance
language <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Romance_language> closely
related to Modern French
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language>. The Norman language in
England eventually developed into Anglo-Norman
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Norman_language>. Because Norman
was spoken primarily by the elites and nobles, while the lower classes
continued speaking Anglo-Saxon, the influence of Norman consisted of
introducing a wide range of loanwords
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loanwords> related to politics,
legislation and prestigious social domains.^[40]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech200639-40> Middle English also greatly
simplified the inflectional system, probably in order to reconcile Old
Norse and Old English, which were inflectionally different but
morphologically similar. The distinction between nominative and
accusative case was lost except in personal pronouns, the instrumental
case was dropped, and the use of the genitive case was limited to
describing possession
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Possession_(linguistics)>. The
inflectional system regularised many irregular inflectional forms,^[41]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass1992-41> and gradually simplified the system of
agreement, making word order less flexible.^[42]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischervan_der_Wurff2006111–13-42> By the Wycliffe
Bible <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wycliffe_Bible> of the 1380s, the
passage Matthew 8:20 was written

    /Foxis han dennes, and briddis of heuene han nestis/^[43]
    <#cite_note-43> 

Here the plural suffix /-n/ on the verb /have/ is still retained, but
none of the case endings on the nouns are present.

By the 12th century Middle English was fully developed, integrating both
Norse and Norman features; it continued to be spoken until the
transition to early Modern English around 1500. Middle English
literature includes Geoffrey Chaucer
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer>'s /The Canterbury Tales
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Canterbury_Tales>/, and Malory's
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Malory> /Le Morte d'Arthur
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Le_Morte_d%27Arthur>/. In the Middle
English period, the use of regional dialects in writing proliferated,
and dialect traits were even used for effect by authors such as Chaucer.


      Early Modern English

Main article: Early Modern English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_Modern_English>
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Great_Vowel_Shift2a.svg>
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Great_Vowel_Shift2a.svg>
Graphic representation of the Great Vowel Shift
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Vowel_Shift>, showing how the
pronunciation of the long vowels gradually shifted, with the high vowels
i: and u: breaking into diphthongs and the lower vowels each shifting
their pronunciation up one level

The next period in the history of English was Early Modern English
(1500–1700). Early Modern English was characterised by the Great Vowel
Shift <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Vowel_Shift> (1350–1700),
inflectional simplification, and linguistic standardisation.

The Great Vowel Shift affected the stressed long vowels of Middle
English. It was a chain shift
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chain_shift>, meaning that each shift
triggered a subsequent shift in the vowel system. Mid
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid_vowel> and open vowels
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_vowel> were raised
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raising_(phonology)>, and close vowels
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_vowel> were broken
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vowel_breaking> into diphthongs
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diphthong>. For example, the word /bite/
was originally pronounced as the word /beet/ is today, and the second
vowel in the word /about/ was pronounced as the word /boot/ is today.
The Great Vowel Shift explains many irregularities in spelling since
English retains many spellings from Middle English, and it also explains
why English vowel letters have very different pronunciations from the
same letters in other languages.^[44] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass2000-44>
^[45] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGörlach199166–70-45>

English began to rise in prestige, relative to Norman French, during the
reign of Henry V <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_V_of_England>.
Around 1430, the Court of Chancery
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Court_of_Chancery> in Westminster
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westminster> began using English in its
official documents <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Writ>, and a new
standard form of Middle English, known as Chancery Standard
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chancery_Standard>, developed from the
dialects of London and the East Midlands
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Midlands_English>. In 1476, William
Caxton <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Caxton> introduced the
printing press <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Printing_press> to England
and began publishing the first printed books in London, expanding the
influence of this form of English.^[46]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTENevalainenTieken-Boon_van_Ostade2006274–79-46>
Literature from the Early Modern period includes the works of William
Shakespeare <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Shakespeare> and the
translation of the Bible
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_James_Version> commissioned by King
James I <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_VI_and_I>. Even after the
vowel shift the language still sounded different from Modern English:
for example, the consonant clusters
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consonant_cluster> /kn ɡn sw/ in
/knight/, /gnat/, and /sword/ were still pronounced. Many of the
grammatical features that a modern reader of Shakespeare might find
quaint or archaic represent the distinct characteristics of Early Modern
English.^[47] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTECercignani1981-47>

In the 1611 King James Version of the Bible, written in Early Modern
English, Matthew 8:20 says:

    /The Foxes haue holes and the birds of the ayre haue nests/^[37]
    <#cite_note-FOOTNOTELass200646–47-37> 

This exemplifies the loss of case and its effects on sentence structure
(replacement with Subject-Verb-Object word order, and the use of /of/
instead of the non-possessive genitive), and the introduction of
loanwords from French (/ayre/) and word replacements (/bird/ originally
meaning "nestling" had replaced OE /fugol/).


      Spread of Modern English

By the late 18th century, the British Empire
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Empire> had facilitated the
spread of English through its colonies and geopolitical dominance.
Commerce, science and technology, diplomacy, art, and formal education
all contributed to English becoming the first truly global language.
English also facilitated worldwide international communication.^[48]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHow_English_evolved_into_a_global_language2010-48>
^[9] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThe_Routes_of_English-9> As England continued
to form new colonies, these, in turn, became independent and developed
their own norms for how to speak and write the language. English was
adopted in North America, India, parts of Africa, Australasia, and many
other regions. In the post-colonial period, some of the newly created
nations that had multiple indigenous languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indigenous_language> opted to continue
using English as the official language to avoid the political
difficulties inherent in promoting any one indigenous language above the
others.^[49] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine2006586-49> ^[50]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMufwene2006614-50> ^[51]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthrup201381–86-51> In the 20th century the
growing economic and cultural influence of the United States and its
status as a superpower <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superpower>
following the Second World War has, along with worldwide broadcasting in
English by the BBC <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC>^[52]
<#cite_note-52> and other broadcasters, significantly accelerated the
spread of the language across the planet.^[53]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddol2006-53> ^[54]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a-54> By the 21st century, English was
more widely spoken and written than any language has ever been.^[55]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCrumMacNeilCran20039–10-55>

A major feature in the early development of Modern English was the
codification of explicit norms for standard usage, and their
dissemination through official media such as public education and
state-sponsored publications. In 1755 Samuel Johnson
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_Johnson> published his /A
Dictionary of the English Language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Dictionary_of_the_English_Language>/
which introduced a standard set of spelling conventions and usage norms.
In 1828, Noah Webster <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noah_Webster>
published the /American Dictionary of the English language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Webster%27s_Dictionary>/ in an effort to
establish a norm for speaking and writing American English that was
independent from the British standard. Within Britain, non-standard or
lower class dialect features were increasingly stigmatised, leading to
the quick spread of the prestige varieties among the middle
classes.^[56] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine19991–56-56>

In terms of grammatical evolution, Modern English has now reached a
stage where the loss of case is almost complete (case is now only found
in pronouns, such as /he/ and /him/, /she/ and /her/, /who/ and /whom/),
and where SVO word-order is mostly fixed.^[56]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine19991–56-56> Some changes, such as the use of
do-support <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Do-support> have become
universalised. (Earlier English did not use the word "do" as a general
auxiliary as Modern English does; at first it was only used in question
constructions where it was not obligatory.^[57]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine19992-57> Now, do-support with the verb
/have/ is becoming increasingly standardised.) The use of progressive
forms in /-ing/, appears to be spreading to new constructions, and forms
such as /had been being built/ are becoming more common. Regularisation
of irregular forms also slowly continues (e.g. /dreamed/ instead of
/dreamt/), and analytical alternatives to inflectional forms are
becoming more common (e.g. /more polite/ instead of /politer/). British
English is also undergoing change under the influence of American
English, fuelled by the strong presence of American English in the media
and the prestige associated with the US as a world power. ^[58]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeechHundtMairSmith200918–19-58> ^[59]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMairLeech2006-59> ^[60]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMair2006-60>


    Geographical distribution

See also: List of territorial entities where English is an official
language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_territorial_entities_where_English_is_an_official_language>,
List of countries by English-speaking population
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_countries_by_English-speaking_population>,
and English-speaking world
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English-speaking_world>
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Map_of_English_native_speakers.png>
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Map_of_English_native_speakers.png>
Percentage of English native speakers.
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Percentage_of_English_speakers_by_country_as_of_2014.png>

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Percentage_of_English_speakers_by_country_as_of_2014.png>
Percentage of English speakers by country.
  80–100%
  60–80%
	
  40–60%
  20–40%
	
  0–20%
  Not available

As of 2016, 400 million people spoke English as their first language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_language>, and 1.1 billion spoke it
as a secondary language.^[61] <#cite_note-61> English is probably the
third largest language by number of native speakers, after Mandarin
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Chinese> and Spanish
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language>.^[10]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEthnologue2010-10> However, when combining native
and non-native speakers it may depending on the estimate used, be the
most commonly spoken language in the world.^[55]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCrumMacNeilCran20039–10-55> ^[62]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a69-62> ^[63] <#cite_note-63> ^[64]
<#cite_note-64> English is spoken by communities on every continent and
on oceanic islands in all the major oceans.^[65]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b106-65>

The countries in which English is spoken can be grouped into different
categories by how English is used in each country. The "inner
circle"^[66] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech20062-66> countries with
many native speakers of English share an international standard of
written English and jointly influence speech norms of English around the
world. English does not belong to just one country, and it does not
belong solely to descendants of English settlers. English is an official
language of countries populated by few descendants of native speakers of
English. It has also become by far the most important language of
international communication when people who share no native language
meet anywhere in the world <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lingua_franca>.


      Three circles of English-speaking countries

Braj Kachru <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braj_Kachru> distinguishes
countries where English is spoken with a three circles model
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Circles_of_English>.^[66]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech20062-66> In his model, the "inner
circle" countries are countries with large communities of native
speakers of English, "outer circle" countries have small communities of
native speakers of English but widespread use of English as a second
language in education or broadcasting or for local official purposes,
and "expanding circle" countries are countries where many learners learn
English as a foreign language. Kachru bases his model on the history of
how English spread in different countries, how users acquire English,
and the range of uses English has in each country. The three circles
change membership over time.^[67] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKachru2006196-67>

Braj Kachru's Three Circles of English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Kachru%27s_three_circles_of_English.svg>

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Kachru%27s_three_circles_of_English.svg>
Braj Kachru's /Three Circles of English/.

Countries with large communities of native speakers of English (the
inner circle) include Britain, the United States, Australia, Canada,
Ireland, and New Zealand, where the majority speaks English, and South
Africa, where a significant minority speaks English. The countries with
the most native English speakers are, in descending order, the United
States <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States> (at least 231
million),^[68] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan2013Table_1-68> the United
Kingdom <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom> (60
million),^[69]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOffice_for_National_Statistics2013Key_Points-69>
^[70] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTENational_Records_of_Scotland2013-70> ^[71]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthern_Ireland_Statistics_and_Research_Agency2012Table_KS207NI:_Main_Language-71>
Canada (19 million),^[72] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistics_Canada2014-72>
Australia <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia> (at least 17
million),^[73]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAustralian_Bureau_of_Statistics2013-73> South Africa
(4.8 million),^[74]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistics_South_Africa2012Table_2.5_Population_by_first_language_spoken_and_province_(number)-74>
Ireland <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland> (4.2
million), and New Zealand (3.7 million).^[75]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStatistics_New_Zealand2014-75> In these countries,
children of native speakers learn English from their parents, and local
people who speak other languages or new immigrants learn English to
communicate in their neighbourhoods and workplaces.^[76]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBao2006377-76> The inner-circle countries provide
the base from which English spreads to other countries in the
world.^[67] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKachru2006196-67>

Estimates of the number of English speakers who are second language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second_language> and foreign-language
speakers vary greatly from 470 million to more than 1,000 million
depending on how proficiency is defined.^[11]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003b108–109-11> Linguist David Crystal
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Crystal> estimates that non-native
speakers now outnumber native speakers by a ratio of 3 to 1.^[62]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a69-62> In Kachru's three-circles model,
the "outer circle" countries are countries such as the Philippines
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippines>,^[77]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTERubino2006-77> Jamaica
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamaica>,^[78]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPatrick2006a-78> India, Pakistan, Singapore,^[79]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTELimAnsaldo2006-79> and Nigeria
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nigeria>^[80]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConnell2006-80> ^[81]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchneider2007-81> with a much smaller proportion of
native speakers of English but much use of English as a second language
for education, government, or domestic business, and where English is
routinely used for school instruction and official interactions with the
government.^[82] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20085-82>

Those countries have millions of native speakers of dialect continua
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dialect_continuum> ranging from an
English-based creole
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English-based_creole_languages> to a more
standard version of English. They have many more speakers of English who
acquire English in the process of growing up through day by day use and
listening to broadcasting, especially if they attend schools where
English is the medium of instruction. Varieties of English learned by
speakers who are not native speakers born to English-speaking parents
may be influenced, especially in their grammar, by the other languages
spoken by those learners.^[76] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBao2006377-76> Most
of those varieties of English include words little used by native
speakers of English in the inner-circle countries,^[76]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBao2006377-76> and they may have grammatical and
phonological differences from inner-circle varieties as well. The
standard English of the inner-circle countries is often taken as a norm
for use of English in the outer-circle countries.^[76]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBao2006377-76>

In the three-circles model, countries such as Poland, China, Brazil,
Germany, Japan, Indonesia, Egypt, and other countries where English is
taught as a foreign language make up the "expanding circle".^[83]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20084-83> The distinctions between
English as a first language, as a second language, and as a foreign
language are often debatable and may change in particular countries over
time.^[82] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20085-82> For example, in
the Netherlands <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netherlands> and some
other countries of Europe, knowledge of English as a second language is
nearly universal, with over 80 percent of the population able to use
it,^[84] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEuropean_Commission2012-84> and thus
English is routinely used to communicate with foreigners and often in
higher education. In these countries, although English is not used for
government business, its widespread use puts them at the boundary
between the "outer circle" and "expanding circle". English is unusual
among world languages in how many of its users are not native speakers
but speakers of English as a second or foreign language.^[85]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKachru2006197-85>

Many users of English in the expanding circle use it to communicate with
other people from the expanding circle, so that interaction with native
speakers of English plays no part in their decision to use English.^[86]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKachru2006198-86> Non-native varieties of English
are widely used for international communication, and speakers of one
such variety often encounter features of other varieties.^[87]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBao2006-87> Very often today a conversation in
English anywhere in the world may include no native speakers of English
at all, even while including speakers from several different
countries.^[88] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20087-88>

Pie chart showing the percentage of native English speakers living in
"inner circle" English-speaking countries. Native speakers are now
substantially outnumbered worldwide by second-language speakers of
English (not counted in this chart).

  US (64.3%)
  UK (16.7%)
  Canada (5.3%)
  Australia (4.7%)
  South Africa (1.3%)
  Ireland (1.1%)
  New Zealand (1%)
  Other (5.6%)


      Pluricentric English

English is a pluricentric language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pluricentric_language>, which means that
no one national authority sets the standard for use of the
language.^[89] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20082-89> ^[90]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine1999-90> ^[91]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBaughCable2002-91> ^[92]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20088–9-92> But English is not a
divided language,^[93] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAmmon20081539-93> despite a
long-standing joke originally attributed to George Bernard Shaw
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw> that the United
Kingdom and the United States are "two countries separated by a common
language".^[94] <#cite_note-94> Spoken English, for example English used
in broadcasting, generally follows national pronunciation standards that
are also established by custom rather than by regulation. International
broadcasters are usually identifiable as coming from one country rather
than another through their accents
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accent_(sociolinguistics)>,^[95]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgill2006-95> but newsreader scripts are also
composed largely in international standard written English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_written_English>. The norms of
standard written English are maintained purely by the consensus of
educated English-speakers around the world, without any oversight by any
government or international organisation.^[96]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAmmon20081537–1539-96>

American listeners generally readily understand most British
broadcasting, and British listeners readily understand most American
broadcasting. Most English speakers around the world can understand
radio programmes, television programmes, and films from many parts of
the English-speaking world.^[97]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech2006122-97> Both standard and
non-standard varieties of English can include both formal or informal
styles, distinguished by word choice and syntax and use both technical
and non-technical registers.^[98]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20085–6-98>

The settlement history of the English-speaking inner circle countries
outside Britain helped level dialect distinctions and produce koineised
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koin%C3%A9_language> forms of English in
South Africa, Australia, and New Zealand.^[99]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeumert2006130-99> The majority of immigrants to the
United States without British ancestry rapidly adopted English after
arrival. Now the majority of the United States population are
monolingual English speakers,^[100]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeumert2006131-100> ^[68]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan2013Table_1-68> although English has been given
official status by only 30 of the 50 state governments of the US.^[101]
<#cite_note-101> ^[102] <#cite_note-102>


      English as a global language

See also: Foreign language influences in English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_language_influences_in_English>
and Study of global communication
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Study_of_global_communication>

English has ceased to be an "English language" in the sense of belonging
only to people who are ethnically English.^[103]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTERomaine19995-103> ^[104]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech20061-104> Use of English is growing
country-by-country internally and for international communication. Most
people learn English for practical rather than ideological
reasons.^[105] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKachru2006195-105> Many speakers of
English in Africa have become part of an "Afro-Saxon" language community
that unites Africans from different countries.^[106]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMazruiMazrui1998-106>

As decolonisation proceeded throughout the British Empire in the 1950s
and 1960s, former colonies often did not reject English but rather
continued to use it as independent countries setting their own language
policies.^[50] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMufwene2006614-50> ^[51]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthrup201381–86-51> ^[107]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMesthrie2010594-107> For example, the view of the
English language <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indian_English> among
many Indians has gone from associating it with colonialism to
associating it with economic progress, and English continues to be an
official language of India.^[108] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnnamalai2006-108>
English is also widely used in media and literature, and the number of
English language books published annually in India is the third largest
in the world after the US and UK.^[109]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTESailaja20092–9-109> However English is rarely spoken
as a first language, numbering only around a couple hundred thousand
people, and less than 5% of the population speak fluent English in
India.^[110] <#cite_note-110> ^[111] <#cite_note-111> David Crystal
claimed in 2004 that, combining native and non-native speakers, India
now has more people who speak or understand English than any other
country in the world,^[112] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2004-112> but the
number of English speakers in India is very uncertain, with most
scholars concluding that the United States still has more speakers of
English than India.^[113] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddol2010-113>

Modern English, sometimes described as the first global lingua franca
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lingua_franca>,^[53]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddol2006-53> ^[114]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeierkord2006165-114> is also regarded as the first
world language <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_language>.^[115]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrutt-Griffler2006690–91-115> ^[116]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthrup2013-116> English is the world's most widely
used language in newspaper publishing, book publishing, international
telecommunications, scientific publishing, international trade, mass
entertainment, and diplomacy.^[116]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTENorthrup2013-116> English is, by international
treaty, the basis for the required controlled natural languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controlled_natural_language>^[117]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWojcik2006139-117> Seaspeak
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seaspeak> and Airspeak, used as
international languages
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_auxiliary_language> of
seafaring^[118]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Maritime_Organization2011-118> and
aviation.^[119]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Civil_Aviation_Organization2011-119>
English used to have parity with French and German in scientific
research, but now it dominates that field.^[120]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGordin2015-120> It achieved parity with French
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language> as a language of
diplomacy at the Treaty of Versailles
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles> negotiations in
1919.^[121] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhillipson200447-121> By the time of the
foundation of the United Nations
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations> at the end of World War
II <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II>, English had become
pre-eminent ^[122] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConradRubal-Lopez1996261-122> and
is now the main worldwide language of diplomacy and international
relations.^[123] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichter201229-123> It is one of six
official languages of the United Nations.^[124]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnited_Nations2008-124> Many other worldwide
international organisations, including the International Olympic
Committee
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee>, specify
English as a working language or official language of the organisation.

Many regional international organisations such as the European Free
Trade Association
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association>,
Association of Southeast Asian Nations
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Association_of_Southeast_Asian_Nations>
(ASEAN),^[54] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a-54> and Asia-Pacific
Economic Cooperation
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asia-Pacific_Economic_Cooperation> (APEC)
set English as their organisation's sole working language even though
most members are not countries with a majority of native English
speakers. While the European Union (EU) allows member states to
designate any of the national languages as an official language of the
Union, in practice English is the main working language of EU
organisations.^[125] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAmmon2006321-125>

Although in most countries English is not an official language, it is
currently the language most often taught as a foreign language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foreign_language>.^[53]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGraddol2006-53> ^[54]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2003a-54> In the countries of the EU, English
is the most widely spoken foreign language in nineteen of the
twenty-five member states where it is not an official language (that is,
the countries other than the UK, Ireland and Malta
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malta>). In a 2012 official Eurobarometer
poll, 38 percent of the EU respondents outside the countries where
English is an official language said they could speak English well
enough to have a conversation in that language. The next most commonly
mentioned foreign language, French (which is the most widely known
foreign language in the UK and Ireland), could be used in conversation
by 12 percent of respondents.^[126]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEuropean_Commission201221,_19-126>

A working knowledge of English has become a requirement in a number of
occupations and professions such as medicine^[127]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlcaraz_ArizaNavarro2006-127> and computing. English
has become so important in scientific publishing that more than 80
percent of all scientific journal articles indexed by /Chemical
Abstracts/ in 1998 were written in English, as were 90 percent of all
articles in natural science publications by 1996 and 82 percent of
articles in humanities publications by 1995.^[128]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrutt-Griffler2006694–95-128>

Specialised subsets of English arise spontaneously in international
communities, for example, among international business people, as an
auxiliary language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_auxiliary_language>. This
has led some scholars to develop the study of English as an auxiliary
languages. Globish <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Globish_(Nerriere)>
uses a relatively small subset of English vocabulary (about 1500 words
with highest use in international business English) in combination with
the standard English grammar. Other examples include Simple English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_English_Wikipedia>.

The increased use of the English language globally has had an effect on
other languages, leading to some English words being assimilated into
the vocabularies of other languages. This influence of English has led
to concerns about language death
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Language_death>,^[129]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2002-129> and to claims of linguistic
imperialism
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistic_imperialism>,^[130]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJambor2007-130> and has provoked resistance to the
spread of English; however the number of speakers continues to increase
because many people around the world think that English provides them
with opportunities for better employment and improved lives.^[131]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTESvartvikLeech2006Chapter_12:_English_into_the_Future-131>


Although some scholars mention a possibility of future divergence of
English dialects into mutually unintelligible languages, most think a
more likely outcome is that English will continue to function as a
koineised <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koin%C3%A9_language> language
in which the standard form unifies speakers from around the world.^[132]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECrystal2006-132> English is used as the language for
wider communication in countries around the world.^[133]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrutt-Griffler2006-133> Thus English has grown in
worldwide use much more than any constructed language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constructed_language> proposed as an
international auxiliary language
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_auxiliary_language>,
including Esperanto <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esperanto>.^[134]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTELi2003-134> ^[135]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeierkord2006163-135>


    Phonology

Main article: English phonology
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_phonology>

The phonetics <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonetics> and phonology
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonology> of the English language differ
from one dialect to another, usually without interfering with mutual
communication. Phonological variation affects the inventory of phonemes
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoneme> (i.e. speech sounds that
distinguish meaning), and phonetic variation is differences in
pronunciation of the phonemes. ^[136]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWolfram2006334–335-136> This overview mainly
describes the standard pronunciations
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_language> of the United Kingdom
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Kingdom> and the United States
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States>: Received Pronunciation
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Received_Pronunciation> (RP) and General
American <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_American> (GA) (See
Section below on "Dialects, accents and varieties"
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language#Dialects,_accents,_and_varieties>).

The phonetic symbols used below are from the International Phonetic
Alphabet <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Phonetic_Alphabet>
(IPA).^[137] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarrHoneybone2007-137> ^[138]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBermúdez-OteroMcMahon2006-138> ^[139]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacMahon2006-139>


      Consonants

Main article: English phonology § Consonants
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_phonology#Consonants>

Most English dialects share the same 24 consonant phonemes. The
consonant inventory shown below is valid for Californian American
English,^[140]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Phonetic_Association199941–42-140> and
for RP.^[141] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994534-141>

Consonant phonemes 	Labial
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labial_consonant> 	Dental
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interdental_consonant> 	Alveolar
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alveolar_consonant> 	Post-
alveolar <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postalveolar_consonant> 	Palatal
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palatal_consonant> 	Velar
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velar_consonant> 	Glottal
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glottal_consonant>
Nasal <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nasal_consonant> 		m
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bilabial_nasal> 			n
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dental,_alveolar_and_postalveolar_nasals#Alveolar>
				ŋ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velar_nasal> 	
Stop <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stop_consonant> 	p
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_bilabial_stop> 	b
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_bilabial_stop> 		t
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_dental_and_alveolar_stops#Alveolar>
	d
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_dental_and_alveolar_stops#Alveolar>
		k <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_velar_stop> 	ɡ
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_velar_stop> 	
Affricate <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affricate_consonant> 				tʃ
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_palato-alveolar_affricate> 	dʒ
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_palato-alveolar_affricate> 			
Fricative <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fricative_consonant> 	f
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_labiodental_fricative> 	v
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_labiodental_fricative> 	θ
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_dental_fricative> 	ð
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_dental_fricative> 	s
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_alveolar_fricative#Voiceless_alveolar_sibilant>
	z
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_alveolar_fricative#Voiced_alveolar_sibilant>
	ʃ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_postalveolar_fricative> 	ʒ
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_postalveolar_fricative> 			h
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiceless_glottal_fricative> 	
Approximant <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Approximant_consonant> 				l
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dental,_alveolar_and_postalveolar_lateral_approximants>
		ɹ
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alveolar_and_postalveolar_approximants>* 		j
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palatal_approximant#Palatal> 		w
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voiced_labio-velar_approximant> 	

* Conventionally transcribed /r/.

In the table, when obstruents <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obstruent>
(stops, affricates, and fricatives) appear in pairs, such as /p b/, /tʃ
dʒ/, and /s z/, the first is fortis
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fortis_and_lenis> (strong) and the second
is lenis (weak). Fortis obstruents, such as /p tʃ s/ are pronounced with
more muscular tension and breath force than lenis consonants, such as /b
dʒ z/, and are always voiceless
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voicelessness>. Lenis consonants are
partly voiced <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voice_(phonetics)> at the
beginning and end of utterances, and fully voiced between vowels. Fortis
stops such as /p/ have additional articulatory or acoustic features in
most dialects: they are aspirated
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aspirated_consonant> [pʰ] when they occur
alone at the beginning of a stressed syllable, often unaspirated in
other cases, and often unreleased [p̚ ] or pre-glottalised [ˀp] at the
end of a syllable. In a single-syllable word, a vowel before a fortis
stop is shortened: thus /nip/ has a noticeably shorter vowel
(phonetically, but not phonemically) than /nib/ [nɪˑp̬] (see below
<#Vowels>).^[142] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollinsMees200347–53-142>

  * lenis stops: /bin/ [b̥ɪˑn], /about/ [əˈbaʊt], /nib/ [nɪˑb̥]
  * fortis stops: /pin/ [ˈpʰɪn], /spin/ [spɪn], /happy/ [ˈhæpi], /nip/
    [ˈnɪp̚ ] or [ˈnɪˀp]

In RP, the lateral approximant /l/, has two main allophones
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allophone> (pronunciation variants): the
clear or plain [l], as in /light/, and the dark or velarised
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velarized_alveolar_lateral_approximant>
[ɫ], as in /full/.^[143] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah200813-143>
GA has dark /l/ in most cases.^[144]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah200841-144>

  * clear /l/: RP /light/ [laɪt]
  * dark /l/: RP and GA /full/ [fʊɫ], GA /light/ [ɫaɪt]

All sonorants <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sonorant> (liquids /l, r/
and nasals /m, n, ŋ/) devoice when following a voiceless obstruent, and
they are syllabic when following a consonant at the end of a word.^[145]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrintonBrinton201056–59-145>

  * voiceless sonorants: /clay/ [ˈkl̥ɛɪ̯] and /snow/ [ˈsn̥oʊ]
  * syllabic sonorants: /paddle/ [pad.l̩], and /button/ [bʌt.n̩]


      Vowels

Main article: English phonology § Vowels
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_phonology#Vowels>

The pronunciation of vowels varies a great deal between dialects and is
one of the most detectable aspects of a speaker's accent. The table
below lists the vowel phonemes <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoneme>
in Received Pronunciation (RP) and General American (GA), with examples
of words in which they occur from lexical sets
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lexical_set> compiled by linguists. The
vowels are represented with symbols from the International Phonetic
Alphabet; those given for RP are standard in British dictionaries and
other publications.

monophthongs RP <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Received_Pronunciation>
GA <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_American> 	word
iː <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_front_unrounded_vowel> 	i 	n*ee*d
ɪ
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Near-close_near-front_unrounded_vowel>
b*i*d
e <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close-mid_front_unrounded_vowel> 	ɛ 	b*e*d
æ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Near-open_front_unrounded_vowel> 	b*a*ck

	
monophthongs RP <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Received_Pronunciation>
GA <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_American> 	word
(ɪ) 	ɨ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_central_unrounded_vowel>
ros*e*s
ə
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mid_central_vowel#Mid_central_unrounded_vowel>
	comm*a*
ɜː <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-mid_central_unrounded_vowel>
ɜr 	b*ir*d
ʌ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-mid_back_unrounded_vowel> 	b*u*t

	
monophthongs RP <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Received_Pronunciation>
GA <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_American> 	word
uː <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Close_back_rounded_vowel> 	u 	f*oo*d
ʊ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Near-close_near-back_rounded_vowel>
g*oo*d
ɔː <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-mid_back_rounded_vowel> 	ɔ 	p*aw*
ɒ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_back_rounded_vowel> 	cl*o*th
ɑ 	b*o*x
ɑː <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_back_unrounded_vowel> 	br*a*

	
diphthongs RP <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Received_Pronunciation> 	GA
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_American> 	word
eɪ 	b*ay*
əʊ 	oʊ 	r*oa*d
aɪ 	cr*y*
aʊ 	c*ow*
ɔɪ 	b*oy*

In RP, vowel length is phonemic; long vowels
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vowel_length> are marked with a
triangular colon <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangular_colon> ⟨ː⟩ in
the table above, such as the vowel of /need/ [niːd] as opposed to /bid/
[bɪd]. GA does not have long vowels.

In both RP and GA, vowels are phonetically shortened before fortis
consonants <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clipping_(phonetics)> in the
same syllable <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syllable>, like /t tʃ f/,
but not before lenis consonants like /d dʒ v/ or in open syllables:
thus, the vowels of /rich/ [rɪ̆tʃ], /neat/ [niˑt], and /safe/ [sĕɪ̆f] are
noticeably shorter than the vowels of /ridge/ [rɪdʒ], /need/ [niːd], and
/save/ [seɪv], and the vowel of /light/ [lăɪ̆t] is shorter than that of
/lie/ [laɪ]. Because lenis consonants are frequently voiceless at the
end of a syllable, vowel length is an important cue as to whether the
following consonant is lenis or fortis.^[146]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTECollinsMees200346–50-146>

The vowels /ɨ ə/ only occur in unstressed syllables and are a result of
vowel reduction <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vowel_reduction>. Some
dialects do not distinguish them, so that /roses/ and /comma/ end in the
same vowel, a dialect feature called weak-vowel merger
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak-vowel_merger>. GA has an unstressed
/r/-coloured schwa /ɚ/, as in /butter/ [ˈbʌtɚ], which in RP has the same
vowel as the word-final vowel in /comma/.


      Phonotactics

An English syllable includes a syllable nucleus consisting of a vowel
sound. Syllable onset and coda (start and end) are optional. A syllable
can start with up to three consonant sounds, as in /sprint/ /sprɪnt/,
and end with up to four, as in /texts/ /teksts/. This gives an English
syllable the following structure, (CCC)V(CCCC) where C represents a
consonant and V a vowel; the word /strengths/ /strɛŋkθs/ is thus an
example of the most complex syllable possible in English. The consonants
that may appear together in onsets or codas are restricted, as is the
order in which they may appear. Onsets can only have four types of
consonant clusters: a stop and approximant, as in /play/; a voiceless
fricative and approximant, as in /fly/ or /sly/; /s/ and a voiceless
stop, as in /stay/; and /s/, a voiceless stop, and an approximant, as in
/string/.^[147] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrintonBrinton201060-147> Clusters
of nasal and stop are only allowed in codas. Clusters of obstruents
always agree invoicing, and clusters of sibilants and of plosives with
the same point of articulation are prohibited. Furthermore, several
consonants have limited distributions: /h/ can only occur in
syllable-initial position, and /ŋ/ only in syllable-final
position.^[148] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKönig1994537–538-148>


      Stress, rhythm and intonation

See also: Stress and vowel reduction in English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stress_and_vowel_reduction_in_English>
and Intonation in English
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intonation_in_English>

Stress <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stress_(linguistics)> plays an
important role in English. Certain syllables
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syllable> are stressed, while others are
unstressed. Stress is a combination of duration, intensity, vowel
quality, and sometimes changes in pitch. Stressed syllables are
pronounced longer and louder than unstressed syllables, and vowels in
unstressed syllables are frequently reduced
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vowel_reduction> while vowels in stressed
syllables are not.^[149]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEInternational_Phonetic_Association199942-149> Some
words, primarily short function words but also some modal verbs such as
/can/, have weak and strong forms
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_and_strong_forms_in_English>
depending on whether they occur in stressed or non-stressed position
within a sentence.

Stress in English is phonemic <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoneme>,
and some pairs of words are distinguished by stress. For instance, the
word /contract/ is stressed on the first syllable (/ˈkɒntrækt/
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English> /KON-trakt/
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key>) when
used as a noun, but on the last syllable (/kənˈtrækt/
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English> /kən-TRAKT/
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key>) for
most meanings (for example, "reduce in size") when used as a verb.^[150]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOxford_Learner's_Dictionary2015Entry_"contract"-150>
^[151] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMerriam_Webster2015Entry_"contract"-151>
^[152] <#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMacquarie_Dictionary2015Entry_"contract"-152>
Here stress is connected to vowel reduction
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vowel_reduction>: in the noun "contract"
the first syllable is stressed and has the unreduced vowel /ɒ/, but in
the verb "contract" the first syllable is unstressed and its vowel is
reduced to /ə/. Stress is also used to distinguish between words and
phrases, so that a compound word receives a single stress unit, but the
corresponding phrase has two: e.g. /to búrn óut/ versus /a búrnout/, and
/a hótdog/ versus /a hót dóg/.^[153]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrintonBrinton201066-153>

In terms of rhythm <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhythm>, English is
generally described as a stress-timed
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stress-timed> language, meaning that the
amount of time between stressed syllables tends to be equal. Stressed
syllables are pronounced longer, but unstressed syllables (syllables
between stresses) are shortened. Vowels in unstressed syllables are
shortened as well, and vowel shortening causes changes in vowel quality
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vowel_quality>: vowel reduction
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vowel_reduction>.


      Regional variation

[show <#>]Varieties of Standard English and their features^[154]
<#cite_note-FOOTNOTETrudgillHannah20024–6-154>
Phonological
features 	United
States <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_English> 	Canada
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_English> 	Republic
of Ireland <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiberno-English> 	Northern
Ireland <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ulster_English> 	Scotland
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scottish_English> 	England
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language_in_England> 	Wales
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Welsh_English> 	South
Africa <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_African_English> 	Australia
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_English> 	New
Zealand <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Zealand_English>
/father/–/bother/ merger
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Father-bother_merger> 	yes 	yes 								
/ɒ/ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English> is unrounded
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unrounded> 	yes 	yes 	yes 							
/ɜːr/ <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/English> is pronounced
[ɚ] 	yes 	yes 	yes 	yes

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cot-caught_merger> 	possibly 	yes

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full%E2%80%93fool_merger> 				yes 	yes

<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flapping> (/latter-ladder merger/)
yes 	yes 	possibly 	often 	rarely 	rarely 	rarely 	rarely 	yes 	often
/trap/–/bath/ split <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trap-bath_split>
